Prerequisites

In this text, we explore how the human body served as the basis for numerical systems. For more details, we recommend starting with:

• Drawing to count: show how we change from our fingers to geometric pictures.
  • Numerical families: Illustrating the relationship between our ancestors and numbers.
  • Numerical families (Part II): Presents the names of generations and numerical orders to the reader.

Growth

In a previous text, we explored how indigenous peoples did not expand their numerical values from right to left. Instead, they chose to grow their numbers in the direction we associate with growth—the vertical (History Tracers Team, , Numerical Families (Part II)). In this text, we will learn how indigenous cultures represented even larger numbers.

Mesoamerican numbers

We can represent any decimal number within the Mesoamerican numerical system. However, it is important to note that this representation is an approximation, as it does not precisely align with the Mesoamerican calendar (Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , pp. 26 - 29, 34 (ResearchGate) ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , pp. 26 - 29, 34 (Revista) ; Puente, Francisco Barriga, , pp. 32, 34, 107 ; Catepillán, Ximena, ). Additionally, we must remember that we only advance to the next numerical "generation" after reaching the number 19, rather than 9, as in the decimal system. We will explore more mathematical concepts to better understand this.

Andean numerical systems

Quipus

Quipus operate under the same principles as our decimal system, with the key difference being that instead of adding numbers to the left when writing larger numbers, knots are added above.
Figure 1: Quipu representation. The source code is available in GitHub of the project (History Tracers Team, , Source-code).

The Yuapana

The "Yupana Inka Tawa Pukllay" method utilized on this page was developed and published by Dhavit Prem (Prem, Dhavit) of the Yupanki Association (Prem, Dhavit, , pp. 354 - 363). This method follows the vertical model of Yupana, as presented by Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 361 - 362). When the maximum value, nine (9), is reached, calculations continue in the row above.
The relationship between Yupana orders and decimal orders is straightforward, as both systems use the same range of numbers:

Conclusion

In this text, we deepened our understanding of various Indigenous numerical systems, exploring both their differences and their similarities with our modern numerical system. To conclude, we invite you to reflect:

?
Reflection 1: Is there a last number?
We explored various numerical systems used for different types of counting, and in none did we find a rule that prevents the addition of more numbers. Could there be a final number in these systems?
